messages: efa521abd0dcb30ad45f52bf45a87f3d (00:19): +Is there a way to include a common header everytime I open the editor?
efa521abd0dcb30ad45f52bf45a87f3d (00:20): +specifically on certain file types.. like *.c *.pl etc
efa521abd0dcb30ad45f52bf45a87f3d (00:20): +jamessan, cool. will check into it
cefab1a2583f7155133fbd8dee7f77e6 (00:31): +hello, how do i see ctrl characters in vim, like tabs?
964081c87da6afc83d5a887c3cec56f8 (00:32): -Hi, can someone remind me what the command is to auto indent my PHP file,
964081c87da6afc83d5a887c3cec56f8 (00:32): -Its not indented and I want it to indent it all
2a14baa4479d675075ce13b3e8cfc756 (00:37): +Cornella, that's a range for a single letter
964081c87da6afc83d5a887c3cec56f8 (00:37): -Does anyone know how the auto Indent? I dont mean switch to Auto Indent... but to auto indent the whole file
dec88c6a4557a376b7f39387c3816221 (00:37): -is it possible to do a :s// on a block selection?
964081c87da6afc83d5a887c3cec56f8 (00:37): -I have just written it... in another editor, but I want to use vim to do it
964081c87da6afc83d5a887c3cec56f8 (00:38): -What do I enter I cant rmember
964081c87da6afc83d5a887c3cec56f8 (00:38): -I used to do it all the time
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (00:38): +well, \w is definitely right. Oh, it's [:alpha:] or [:alnum:]  -- :he pattern
964081c87da6afc83d5a887c3cec56f8 (00:38): -But Ive forgotten and its annoying, its like 3000 lines and I cant make my way through it anymore without indentation properly but ive changed it so much
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (00:40): +it'll automagically do the right thing if you're in visual mode.
dec88c6a4557a376b7f39387c3816221 (00:41): -:s works over line ranges, not inside visual blocks.  (and i just tried it.)
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (00:41): +no, it won't. you need to use \%V
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (00:42): +I guess I misunderstand the question...
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (00:43): +Zathrus: the key word was block. you were correct for visual line selections
dec88c6a4557a376b7f39387c3816221 (00:43): -maybe you were think vusial linewise selections
0c4b1a16ac03c3ce195bbe0fc75c8130 (00:58): +How do I change a dos-formatted text file to unix format? The newlines are messed up.
0c4b1a16ac03c3ce195bbe0fc75c8130 (00:59): +victori: well... I have tried the last, but it did not work.
0c4b1a16ac03c3ce195bbe0fc75c8130 (01:00): +Zathrus: yeah. But I would like to know the "right" way to do this.
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (01:00): +tdn: that is the right way -- it strips off the ^M's. Works in vim, vi, nvi, etc
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (01:01): +if you don't actually want to get rid of the ^M's then :set ffs is proper
0c4b1a16ac03c3ce195bbe0fc75c8130 (01:01): +Zathrus: I want to get rid of the ^M's.
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (01:02): +tdn: then use the :%s I gave
0c4b1a16ac03c3ce195bbe0fc75c8130 (01:02): +Zathrus: ok. But the ^v is actually ctrl+v, right?
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (01:02): +or use dos2unix (if available) or tr to fix the file outside of the editor
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (01:03): +tdn: both are ctrl-v and ctrl-m (although Enter usually works for ctrl-m)
0c4b1a16ac03c3ce195bbe0fc75c8130 (01:03): +Zathrus: but that is not good, if I want to use it in a vim-script, right?
0c4b1a16ac03c3ce195bbe0fc75c8130 (01:04): +Zathrus: I am thinking of mapping it to a key in my .vimrc.
878b627b013f0c465ec2be26325ce80d (01:05): +vim scripts are just vim commands. no reason that shouldn't work
0c4b1a16ac03c3ce195bbe0fc75c8130 (01:06): +jamessan: but if I insert an ^M char in a script - a new line appears (on dos systems)
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (01:06): +newline on DOS is CR/LF -- not just CR alone
fb2c4f3e688db2a676f292cd15961a59 (01:06): +it'd probably hose up on Macs though
